quote: Of course he would've...
The latinum's not on the station. I've looked everywhere. Evade. I even had my brother scan for it with the internal sensors.
At least you have the painting.
Forget the painting, I want that latinum.
If you think it'll make you happy. Confront.
Believe me, it will. This is the break I've been waiting for, and it's been a long time coming. I want Morn's money, I need Morn's money. I deserve Morn's money.
Your move.
Beautiful, isn't it? And the way it catches the light... I wonder who came up with the idea of suspending liquid latinum inside worthless bricks of gold?
Probably somebody who got tired of making change with an eyedropper. Are you going to play or not?
Where could Morn have put it all?
If you find it, are you really going to share it with this woman?
I agreed to give her ten percent so she wouldn't tie me up in court.
That's a hundred bricks.
What could I do? Retreat.
I don't know. Something's not right about this whole thing.
I don't trust this woman.
Neither do I. But that doesn't mean I'm going to keep her away from my lobes.
Just keep your eyes open. Don't be fooled by a pretty face.
Not me.
Of course not. Acquire.
Larell? What a pleasant surprise. Computer, lights.
Do you like surprises, Quark?
Only pleasant ones.
I like to think I'm pleasant. Do you think I'm pleasant?
Absolutely.
Then I guess this qualifies as a pleasant surprise.
What are you doing in my quarters?
My brother and I were business associates of Morn's.
If you came for the memorial service, it was yesterday.
Was it nice?
It was lovely.
I understand you inherited Morn's estate.
That's right.
We were business associates of Morn's.
Your brother mentioned that.
He borrowed some money from us. We'd like his estate to repay the loan.
How much money are we talking about?
One thousand bricks of gold- pressed latinum.
I had a feeling you were going to say that.
Obviously I need to see some documentation regarding this loan.
We shook hands.
(moving to stand behind Quark) We trusted Morn.
And I'm sure he'd want you to honor his word.
I'm sure he would. But you have to understand, Morn's assets are tied up in his various enterprises.
I hope you're not saying you don't have the money.
That wouldn't be good.
All I meant was that it's going to take me a little while to get it.
You do know where it is?
Of course.
However, you're not the first creditors to make a claim against his estate.
We're not?

Morn was expanding his business interests when he died. His resources were stretched somewhat thin. As a result, the claims against his estate are greater than its assets. Obviously you can't expect full repayment.
What can we expect?
A percentage.
What sort of percentage?
Twenty.
We couldn't accept anything less than eighty.
I don't like beets.
We'll take seventy.
Forty, and because I can see you both have fine taste, I'm willing to part with this.
It was Morn's most treasured possession. Beautiful, isn't it?
Nice.
We won't take less than sixty.
Forty's the best I can do.
Fifty.
Sorry.
Fifty it is.
I'm glad we were able to come to an understanding.
Me too.
We'll be watching you, Quark. Don't try anything.
Me? Don't be ridiculous.
What do we have here... ?
Computer, what is this?
A claim slip for storage locker one-thirty-seven located in the station's Assay Office.
A storage locker... Thank you, computer. You've been very helpful.
Morn, wherever you are, I love you!
What do you mean I have to open it in here?
Regulations -- the contents of a deceased person's storage locker have to be inspected by station security.
There's no such regulation, you just want to know what's inside.
You are so transparent. I can't wait to see your face when your deputies wheel in my thousand bricks of latinum.
That can't be it.
(checks the label, smiles) Storage locker one-thirty-seven.
Well, sometimes good things come in small packages...
Is that going to be enough to cover Morn's bar tab?
It's covered. There's more where this came from.
What makes you say that?
Take a look.
On the bottom. Recognize Morn's handwriting?
"The rest is in the Bank of Bolias."
Account number CJ57436.
It wasn't listed in Morn's financial records...
Who cares? (tucking the brick into his vest) Now if you'll excuse me, I'm going to contact the bank and let them know that Morn's legal heir would like his latinum delivered as soon as possible...
Larell...
I've been looking all over for you...
I'm a busy man.
Not too busy to look for a certain something, I hope?
Actually, I haven't had much luck with that.
Sounds like you need some motivation...
I'm motivated, believe me. It's just going to take some time to locate, that's all. I've got an idea! Why don't you go back to... wherever you came from -- and I'll contact you as soon as I find it.
I'd rather wait here. With you.
This is no time for oo-mox...
You don't like it?
It's not that, it's just... the sooner I find that certain something, the sooner you and I can take our little trip together.
You're so diligent. Most men don't know how to defer gratification.
You don't make it easy...
Level Seventeen.
You're good. But I'm the only one the bank's going to give the money to. (repeating the number so he won't forget) CJ57436. CJ57436. CJ5 --
This is my stop.
What's your hurry?
My brother has something he wants to say to you.
I'm sorry. About the painting.
He feels terrible.
(trying to move past them) No hard feelings.
It's nice of you to be so forgiving, Quark.
Don't mention it.
My brother has a terrible temper.
I get upset.
It comes out when things don't go our way.
I noticed.
That's why I'm hoping things start to go our way soon. Do you understand what I'm saying?
I think I do, yes.
I don't like to get upset.
Don't worry, things are going to go your way soon.
That's good to hear.
I'll be in touch.
Sorry about the painting.
--36. CJ57436. Bank of Bolias...
Making a withdrawal, Quark? Let me guess -- a thousand bricks of gold-pressed latinum.
Put your hands on your head and turn around.
All right, how much do you want? And don't ask for the whole thousand bricks, I already gave away more than half of it.
Attempted bribery. That should add a few years to your sentence.
What are you talking about?
Let's go.
Go where? Who are you?
Lurian Security. I have a signed extradition order for your arrest. (waving him toward the door again) As soon as your station's security chief approves it, we'll be on our way.
But what did I do -- what's the charge?
Conspiracy to intercept government property.
Government property?
One thousand bricks of gold pressed latinum.
Wait a minute. Morn won that latinum in the Lissepian lottery.
He didn't?
It was his bequest from the royal family of Luria.
Why would the royal family of Luria give Morn that kind of money?
He was the crown prince.
Morn was a prince?
You didn't know?
Morn was a prince?
That's what I'm saying.
Morn was a prince...
Yes. But he renounced the throne when he came of age.
I always knew he was an idiot.
His family bequeathed him the latinum when he abdicated. Now that he's deceased, it's legally theirs again.
He left it to me.
The will has already been nullified. He signed an agreement to return the latinum in the event of his death.
Oh. Do me a favor, don't tell his ex- wife that. I'm going to need a little oo-mox later.
His ex-wife?
Larell.
She's here?
I just saw her.
Something wrong?
Quiet. Let me think.
Listen and listen carefully. Larell has been trying to get her hands on the Prince's latinum for years. She's tried blackmail, extortion -- I wouldn't be surprised if she was behind his death.
She's always been nice to me...
The royal family would like nothing better than to see her behind bars. If you help me apprehend her, there'll be a substantial reward.
What do I have to do?
When are you going to see her again?
She'll turn up sooner or later. If not her, those two brothers.
Brothers?
They said they were Morn's business partners. They claim he owed them money. Something tells me they're not exactly above board.
Whoever these brothers are, I promise you I'm not going to let them get between the royal family and its latinum.
And I'm not going to let anything get between me and my reward.
Then we have an understanding.
If I'm going to put these people away, I need to catch them trying to get their hands on the latinum. Contact the bank -- tell them to deliver it here.
Then what?
Try to stay out of sight. Leave the rest to me.
What are you doing?
Trying to fix this optronic relay.
Wouldn't you be better off working in a lab?
I'm keeping Morn's chair warm.
Good man.
Where's Quark? I'm in the mood for one of his famous Til'amin froths.
You'll have to settle for something else. He's in the back. (motioning to a Ferengi waiter) And from what Broik tells me, he's not coming out.
Sounds like he's taking Morn's death pretty hard.
He loved the guy. I'd better go test this.
I'll take over.
Good man.
Anybody here?
What a surprise...
You've got to help me, Quark. Someone's been following me.
Who?
Two men.
Brothers?
How should I know?
That could be them.
Don't answer it.
Believe me, I'm not planning to.
They're trying to bypass the lock.
Come on.
Computer, dim lights.
Remind me to invest in a better lock...
Stay here.
Gentlemen.
We've been looking all over for you, Quark.
The latinum's on its way. It'll be here tomorrow.
That's good news. We were starting to worry.
Expecting anyone?
You never know when someone's going to drop by.
Don't answer it.
Sounds like they're coming in anyway.
You should invest in a better lock.
Whoever it is, get rid of them. (indicating the partition) We'll be back there.
You'd be more comfortable in there.
We'll be back there.
Why didn't you answer the door?
I dozed off. It's been one of those days.
We need to talk.
What would we have to talk about?
Are you all right?
What makes you ask that?
You keep craning your neck.
Well look what we have here...
I'll bet the royal family sleeps soundly knowing you're on the job...
Royal family? What kind of lies have you been telling him, Hain?
The usual.
You know each other?
It's been a long time.
Must be nine years.
Nine years.
I see you're still one step behind everyone else.
Leave him alone, Hain.
It's Larell.
I can see that.
What is going on here?
We're having a little reunion. (lowering Nahsk's weapon) We used to work together. With Morn.
I guess that means he wasn't really a Prince after all.
And you're not really a security agent?
And you're not really his ex-wife?
Please don't tell me Morn didn't have any latinum.
Oh, he had latinum, all right.
At least that part's true...
Ever hear of the Lissepian Mother's Day heist?

Who hasn't? While the whole planet was celebrating, someone broke into the Central Bank and made off with -- (realizing as he says it) One thousand bricks of gold- pressed latinum. Wait a minute. You expect me to believe that the four of you pulled that off?
(not realizing they've been insulted) The five of us. Morn helped.
Yeah, and then he ran off with the latinum.
Why did it take you so long to come after him?
Because we knew he'd stashed it away somewhere to wait for the statute of limitations to expire.
And it did. Two weeks ago.
You see, we can't be prosecuted anymore.
So... here we are. And the latinum's en route. Maybe we should just split it up and go our separate ways.
The voice of reason.
Not you, us.
Krit's right, we don't need him anymore.
You know, we don't need him anymore.
What do we do with him?
It should look like an accident. We don't want anyone asking questions.
Wait a minute. You can't kill me. I'm the only one who can take delivery of the latinum. You need my thumbprint.
He's right.
It won't hurt as much if you keep still.
What do you propose we do, Nahsk? Walk into the cargo bay with a bloody thumb and ask for the latinum?
We need him.
The question is, what happens after he takes delivery?
We could split the latinum five ways. It's what you would've gotten if Morn was still alive.
True.
Think of me as Morn. I can't believe I just said that.
It's not fair. We stole it. He didn't do anything.
Maybe not. But the bottom line is, you need me.
A thousand bricks, split five ways... what do you think?
It's still a lot of latinum.
Two hundred and fifty bricks each.
So, do we have a deal?
He's in.
The Bolian transport arrives tomorrow at sixteen hundred hours. We'll meet at the cargo bay.
We're staying together until it gets here.
We are?
I don't trust you, and I certainly don't trust them.
I see your point. But I have a bar to run.
(raising his glass to Quark) To your hospitality.
Don't mention it.
So this was Morn's favorite place...
(pointing to Morn's chair) He used to sit right there.
That's not very smart -- sitting with your back to the door.
He was the trusting type.
Which one of you killed him, anyway?
Come on, it's nothing to be ashamed of.
It wasn't us.
Me neither.
Don't look at me.
So it really was an accident.
Poor Morny. He always did have bad luck.
We had some good times together...
He was always so cheerful.
That's what I loved about him.
It's funny. Being here together, the four of us -- it makes me wish Morn were here, too.
Sure, except we'd have to split the latinum six ways instead of five.
Do you mind?
Some people have no respect for the dead.
Remember that little dance Morn used to do every time we finished a job?
You're thinking of someone else.
Get rid of him.
We're closed.
At this hour?
Friends of Morn. We're commiserating.
I see. (eyeing Morn's "friends") How long are you going to be closed?
Oh, till about sixteen hundred hours tomorrow.
We have a lot to commiserate about.
I see.
Where were we?
I believe that's for me.
Open it.
I'll count it...
All right, someone else count it.
Put it down, Hain. My brother may be slow, but if you pull the trigger, he'll kill you.
I'm not slow.
Nahsk... ?
Go ahead, kill each other...
Security! Drop your weapons!
I surrender.
Throw out your weapon.
Take her to a holding cell and get the rest of them to the Infirmary.
There you are.
Are they gone?
From now on, you'll have to do your commiserating alone. Your "friends" are going to prison.
For how long?
Assault with intent to kill -- long enough.
It's mine... all mine.
What you're about to hear is the most beautiful sound in the galaxy...
This can't be... there's no latinum in these bricks...
What?
(as another brick crumples in his hand) Someone extracted the latinum...
There's nothing here but worthless gold...
And it's all yours...
Quark.
Quark.
What do you want?
There's someone here to see you.
I thought you said they were all going to prison.
You'd better sit down.
Morn?
Alive and well.
Apparently he faked his own death. I'll let him tell you all about it.
Well?
I don't want to hear it! Not a word.
You set me up. You left the latinum to me because you knew I'd do whatever it would take to get
I could've been killed, you know.
And I thought we were friends.
I've got to admit, I didn't suspect for a minute.
To tell you the truth I didn't think you had it in you to pull off something like this.
I've just got one question for you. What happened to the latinum?
Of course, your second stomach. You've been keeping it in your second stomach all these years? That's a lot of latinum. No wonder your hair fell out.
For me? This must be a hundred bricks worth.
I don't know what to say. Thanks. Not that I didn't earn it after what you put me through.
If you ever want to set me up again, feel free.
You know, you and I should consider doing business together.
Two enterprising gentlemen like us could do all right for ourselves. Take that gold dust of yours...
It doesn't have to be a total loss. I hear that in certain primitive cultures it's considered quite valuable...
That's it?
That's it. The "City of B'hala," painted nearly twenty thousand years ago --
Hmm.
Jadzia -- you're looking at the most important Bajoran icon ever painted. The only known "proof" that B'hala actually existed, and all you have to say is "hmm"?
No, it's just that you both gave it such a build up that I thought it would be a lot...
(delineating a larger imaginary canvas) ... bigger.
Not that small is bad.
We've been trying to force the Cardassian government to return this to us since the end of the Occupation. It's good to have it back.
I thought you said it was being returned to the State Museum in Ilvia.
It will be. Tomorrow. But I couldn't let it pass without stealing a look. Sometimes, being the Emissary isn't such a bad thing.
They were all about eleven meters tall... made of hundreds of stones, carved and fitted together so tightly that they didn't need mortar.
It's said they mark the city's place in the cosmos.
Beautiful markings.
Supposedly, they're coordinates of the lost city.
But since we can't see the markings on the other two sides, they're impossible to decipher.
Which is why B'hala is likely to remain lost.
Before you pack it up, have it scanned into the computer.
You're going to study it? Maybe try to find the lost city?
I wouldn't get my hopes up, major. I just like it. I want a copy for my office.
I was just thinking about Zocal's third prophecy. It says that only someone touched by the Prophets could find the ruins of B'hala.
No pressure.
Computer, magnify grid C-four.
A reflection... Now magnify D-two.
Computer. Process Sisko image file three-seven-six. Reduce in size seventy-five percent.
Superimpose grid D-Two.
Reverse image and enhance.
Sorry to disturb you, Captain, but...
But what?
It's after three in the morning.
Three, already?
Time flies when you're having fun.
Quark -- I want you to save this program for me.
What is it?
An ancient puzzle.
You know, Captain, if you like puzzles -- I have a wide assortment of pleasure mazes. And they all come with a surprise in the center.
Never mind, Quark. I'll save the program myself.
Quark to Infirmary -- medical emergency in Holosuite Four.
But Odo -- you said yourself the Captain's all right.
Lucky for you.
Then why am I being arrested? I already told you it was an accident. A minor technical difficulty. You can't arrest somebody for a minor technical difficulty.
No, but I can arrest you for negligence. Your own records show your holosuites are in desperate need of maintenance.

Which is what I've been telling Chief O'Brien for the past week. I begged him to have Rom repair them. But you know what he said? "Rom's too busy upgrading the sensor array." Can you believe that? Anyone can fix a sensor array. But no one can fix the holosuites like that idiot brother of mine. So you see, if anyone should be arrested for negligence, it's Chief O'Brien.
Tell it to the magistrate.
... There are no signs of any permanent neural damage, though I am reading some odd synaptic potentials. Let me ask you something -- does my uniform look a little brighter to you?
Yes... everything does.
Colors seem more intense... and shapes are more... focused.
That's called post-neural shock syndrome. Your neural pathways were overloaded by the plasma burst. All external stimuli are going to seem more pronounced.
In the meantime, enjoy the show.
So... did dinner get the Sisko stamp of approval?
Grandpa would be proud of you.
I was a little worried I overcooked the Lingta roast. I'm glad you liked it.
Can I get you anything else?
I'm fine.
I guess you'll be cooking tomorrow night.
Why's that?
To welcome Kasidy back to the station. Maybe prepare some of that jambalaya she likes so much.
We'll see.
Dad, Kasidy's spent six months in prison for helping the Maquis -- she's paid for what she did.
I suppose so.
I hope you'll give her a chance... that's all. You two had something...
Dad?
Dad -- what is it?
These shapes...
Go ahead.
Sorry to disturb you, Benjamin. But I have Admiral Whatley calling from Starfleet Headquarters.
I'll take it in here.
Hello, Ben.
Admiral.
How've you been?
Never better.
Glad to hear it. I know you've been waiting for this news a long time. I'm glad to be the one who tells you.
Bajor's petition to join the Federation has been approved.
It's about time.
Congratulations, Ben. You've done a helluva job out there.
Thank you.

We're not the only ones who think so. The Bajorans requested that the signing ceremony take place on your station. So make sure you spruce up that floating bicycle wheel of yours. Count on me and a lot of other brass showing up for this one, captain... or should I say admiral? That can't be far away once you have this feather in your cap.
Computer, spotlight.
Drumroll.
Welcome Klingons.
Not that one --
I see you're prepared for anything.
Never hurts.
I take it you think Federation membership is going to be good for business?
Of course it is -- this station is going to get busier than an Alvanian beehive. I'm expecting to do five times the volume in root beer alone.

You see, it's all about foot traffic. The more people come in, the more they drink. The more they drink, the more they talk. The more they talk, the more they let slip things I shouldn't know. And that... that always leads to latinum.
Perhaps so. But there is one problem...
What's that?
An ancient Klingon proverb -- "You cannot loosen a man's tongue with root beer."
... it is wonderful news, Vedek Mera. I'll see you at the signing ceremony.
Enjoying the celebration?
As far as I'm concerned, the Federation should accept a new member every week.
And you, Major? Are you celebrating?

Five years ago, I wouldn't be. I didn't think Federation membership was right for Bajor. It hadn't been that long since the occupation and I thought it was important for us to learn to stand on our own two feet.
What changed your mind?
A lot of things. My time on the station... my dealings with Starfleet... but mostly, the captain.
He can be very persuasive.
No doubt about that. He's made me a believer.
I'll drink to that.
Where is the Captain? I want to congratulate him.
He was here for a little while, but I think he went back to the holosuite.
Don't worry, I fixed them.
Captain...
Sir... something wrong?
Captain!
Benjamin!
Major?
Are you all right?
I was there.
Sir?
B'hala. It was the eve of the Peldor Festival. I could hear them ringing the temple chimes.
You were dreaming.
No, I was there. I could smell the burning bateret leaves, taste the incense on the wind.

I was standing in front of the Obelisk. And as I looked up, for a moment, I understood it all. B'hala... the Orbs... the occupation... the discovery of the wormhole... the coming war with the Dominion.
You could see the future as well as the past?
And for one moment, I could see the pattern that held it all together.
You had a pagh'tem'far -- a sacred vision.
I don't know what I had. But it felt... wonderful.
The Prophets chose well when they made you their Emissary. So how does it all fit together?
I wish I knew. Someone woke me up.
I was worried about you.
I understand. If I found you in the middle of a pagh'tem'far, I'd probably be worried, too.
O'Brien to Captain Sisko.
Go ahead.
Sir, I've just received word that Kai Winn is on her way to the station. She should arrive in less than two hours.
Thank you, Chief. Major Kira will greet her at the airlock.
Make my apologies.
Tell the Kai I'll meet with her tomorrow, but today I'm busy... (tries to come up with an excuse, can't) Make something up.
Where are you going to be?
Right here. The answer's in that Spire. I know it.
Kai Winn.
Greetings, my child. You look... very sweet.
Looks can be deceiving. But you don't need me to tell you that.
Why isn't the Emissary here to greet me?
I'm afraid Captain Sisko is busy at the moment.
No doubt he's still basking in the adulation of Starfleet Command.
Something like that.
I'm sure the Federation is very pleased with the job he's done.
I thought everyone was.
Not everyone. Our culture has only had five short years to recover from the Occupation. Only five years of freedom. Hardly seems enough time, does it?
Bajor will still be free. Joining the Federation won't change that.
I see working beside Captain Sisko all these years has had quite an influence on you.
I have to give you credit. You never give up. I'm sure the Emissary will consider everything you have to say. And then Bajor's admittance can go forward... unobstructed.
I await the will of the Prophets.
Hello, Ben.
Kasidy.
Jake said I could find you...
Something wrong?
Not at all. I'm just a little surprised. I wasn't sure you'd be happy to see me.
What are you doing for the next few hours?
I don't know. I just got here.
Why don't you come to Bajor with me?
Right now?
I think I know where to find B'hala. The sacred lost city of Bajor.
You see these markings? They're a coordinate system keyed to the position of the stars at a certain time of night... You don't have the faintest idea what I'm talking about, do you?
Not a clue.
Come to Bajor and I'll show you.
I'm not even sure where I'm staying yet.
You can have your old quarters back... if you want them.
They're still available?
Everything's just the way you left it. I have some pull with the station's C.O.
Ben.
I've missed you.
I'm glad you're back. Now what do you say we go find B'hala?
Now what do you say we go find B'hala?
Somehow, I don't think you're going to take "no" for an answer.
This way.
We must be two hundred meters underground. I don't want to be negative, Ben... but this doesn't look like a lost city to me.
What you're looking at is twenty thousand years worth of sediment. Stay close and watch your step. We're not far from --
What's the matter?
It's nothing. I'll be fine in a second. Julian said headaches might be a side effect of the accident.
What about obsessing over an ancient Bajoran city? Is that a side effect, too?
You're being negative again.
C'mon -- it's right around the bend.
What is it?
It's B'hala.
Ben, it's a wall of stone.
But what's behind the wall?
Those quarters are not appropriate for Admiral Colti. She outranks Admiral Veta.
Then let's put her in H-Two, Veta goes to D-Nine, and Rifkin in K- Four.
But he's only a captain.
It's a naval tradition.
So is keelhauling. But right now, we should focus on accommodations.
Don't you agree, major?
Hmm?
Sorry, I didn't mean to interrupt your reverie.
I was just thinking about Captain Sisko finding B'hala. Bajoran archaeologists have been searching for the sacred city for ten thousand years. And he found it in a few days.
Or he made a very lucky guess.
It was a sign. A sign from the Prophets.
I wonder if the Prophets can help us find quarters for Captain Rifkin.
Of course. Good luck.
I was about to say the same to you.
My child, you and the Emissary are... close, are you not?
I consider Captain Sisko a friend.
So you know his mind. How he thinks... how he reacts in certain situations...
I'm not really sure what you're asking.
I'm asking if you think the Emissary will forgive me.
Forgive you?
For doubting him. He must be aware that I never truly believed he was the Emissary.
I'm sure it crossed his mind.
I was wrong. I know that now. only someone touched by the Prophets could find B'hala.
Does this mean you're not going to try to block Bajor's admittance into the Federation?
I will follow the path the Emissary has laid out for us.
I have to admit, I'm surprised to hear that. It takes a lot of courage to admit you're wrong.
And you think I lack courage?
I didn't say that.
But it is what you think. Those of you who were in the Resistance -- you're all the same. You think you're the only ones who fought the Cardassians... that you saved Bajor singlehandedly.

Perhaps you forget, major, that the Cardassians arrested any Bajoran they found teaching the word of the Prophets. I spent five years in a Cardassian prison camp... I can remember each and every beating that I suffered. And where you had weapons to protect yourself, all I had was my faith... and my courage. Walk with the Prophets, child. I know I will.
Hello, Admiral.
Ben.
So this is the ancient city of Balla.
B'hala.
Missing for twenty thousand years and you found it. Pretty impressive. Sure as hell impressed the Bajorans. How'd you know where to look?
You might say it came to me in a vision.
I know that's what the Bajorans think. But just between you and me... what really happened?
I know it's hard to understand... but it really was a vision. For the last few days, I've been having these moments of insight... flashes of understanding.
And they started after you had the accident?
I don't know, Ben. This is a little strange.
You didn't come down here to see B'hala, did you, Admiral?
No. I came to see you. I was surprised you weren't on the station when I arrived.
I'm sorry about that.
Not sorry enough to return my com signals... all three of them...

Ben, I need to know I can count on you. Bajor's admission is only the beginning. Now comes the hard part Federation council members have to be chosen... the Bajoran militia has to be absorbed into Starfleet... there are thousands of details that have to be overseen. And you're our point man here. That means we need to depend on you more than ever.
Don't worry, I won't let you down.
I'm glad to here that. Now, what do you say we get back up to the station?
I can't go back to the station. Not just yet.
Why not? I'm sure the Bajorans can take it from here. Or were you thinking of digging up the entire city all by yourself?
Charlie, I just need a little more time.
For what?
To find answers. (knows this isn't very helpful) There's clarity here. I wish I could explain it better, but I can't.
You're scaring me with this, Ben.
I'm a little scared myself.
All right, I'll give you some time. But I want you back on the station by oh-seven-hundred hours, tomorrow. You're to report to Doctor Bashir for a complete physical.
I'll be there.
Good. I'll bring the donuts.
It's oh-seven-fifteen. Where the hell is he?
His runabout only docked twenty- five minutes ago. I'm sure he's on his way.
When he gets here, I want you to give him a full work-up.
I examined him before he left for Bajor. He didn't complain of any new symptoms, but my scans still showed the same odd synaptic potentials. I was hoping the problem would cure itself by now.
But it hasn't. Isn't there something you can do to help?
I could try neuro-polaric induction, but that's a very serious operation, and I'd rather not do it unless it's absolutely necessary.
So in the meantime, he's going to keep having... "visions." I knew we were headed for trouble the minute he allowed the Bajorans to call him "Emissary."

He didn't have much choice. The Bajorans are deeply committed to their spirituality... not to mention incredibly stubborn. They believe Captain Sisko is the Emissary and nothing is going to change their minds.
Emissary! Emissary!
I told you held be here.
There's no need to worry.
The katterpod harvest will be much better this year.
You don't belong here. Go home.
Captain!
What's wrong?
I'm fine.
Admiral?
What is it, Ben?
Your son... you can stop worrying about him. He forgives you.
How the hell did he know that Kevin and I weren't getting along?
He's the Emissary.
That should do it.
I'll have the test results in a few minutes.
Well, that wasn't so bad, was it?
Captain?
Cardassia.
Sir?
That's where it was going... the cloud.
What cloud?
I was on Bajor. B'hala had been rebuilt. The streets were filled with people... celebrating.

But then a shadow blocked out the sun. We looked up and saw a cloud filling the sky. It was a swarm of locusts. Billions of them. They hovered over the city, the noise was deafening... but just as quickly as they came, they moved on. Now I know where they were going. Cardassia.
What do you think it means?
I don't know.
At least the swarm was moving away from Bajor. That's a good sign. Isn't it?
But what do these locusts represent? And why Cardassia?
You were dreaming. And dreams don't always make sense.
This wasn't a dream.
Captain, why didn't you tell me about these headaches of yours?
I guess I was too busy.

Well, if you had stayed busy much longer you might have died. The area of unusual neural activity has grown another eight percent. As a result, your basal ganglia are starting to depolarize. I'm going to have to operate... try to repolarize the neural sheaths.
How will that affect my visions?
That's not really the issue, is it?
It is to me. (to Bashir; wanting an answer) Doctor?
There's no way to tell. But I assume once I complete the procedure, your brain activity will return to normal and the visions will stop.
considers his options.
Then you can't do it.
Ben, that's ridiculous.
If I don't operate, you could die.
I understand that, but something's happening to me... something extraordinary, and I have to see it through.
What do you mean you're not going to let Doctor Bashir operate? You have to.
Don't you see? These visions are a gift. I can't refuse them.
I can't believe what I'm hearing. Listen to yourself, Ben. Sitting there, telling us that this mystical journey of yours is more important than watching your son grow up.
Dad, please think about what you're doing. These visions... they're not worth dying for.

I remember the first time I held you in my hands. You were just a few minutes old... and when I looked down at your face, it was almost as if I could see your whole life stretched out in front of you -- the joys it would bring... and the bruises. It was all there, hidden in your scrunched up, little face.
The baby I'm holding in my hands now... is the universe itself. And I need time to study its face.
Look at your son's face now, then tell me you're doing the right thing.
Come in.
It's time, Emissary. If you're ready.
I am.
Ready for what?
The Emissary has asked for help in his journey. I'm providing it.
And you trust her? Since when?
It'll be all right, Jake.
I love you. Both of you.
I've never seen the temple so crowded. Seemed like every Bajoran on the station was there to pray for the Emissary.
Glad to hear it. If he's going to survive this, he needs all the help he can get.
The Captain's not going to die. He's the Emissary. The Prophets will take care of him.
With all due respect, Major, I'd rather see Julian take care of him.
Chief, I know you're worried. But the Prophets are leading the Emissary on this path for a reason...
Do not attempt to convince them, Major. They cannot understand.
Since when did you believe in the Prophets?
What I believe in is faith. Without it there can be no victory. If the captain's faith is strong, he will prevail.
That's not much to bet his life on.
You're wrong. Faith is everything.
I hope you're right, major... I hope you're right.
... he asks for your guidance. Let him see with your eyes. Lift the veil of darkness that obscures his path.
Emissary?
I'm ready.
The Orb of Prophecy is quite powerful -- it taxes even the healthy. Are you sure you want to go through with this?
I have to. I need to bring the visions into focus -- tie them together. I can't do it alone.
You're weak. Perhaps you should wait until after the signing.
I may not have time. I need to do this now.
As you wish.
May the Prophets reveal their wisdom to you, Emissary.
He's already an hour late.
He is still consulting the Orb of Prophecy.
And how long do these "Orb experiences" last?
Minutes. Hours. Sometimes days.
Then maybe we shouldn't wait for him. Do you have any objections to proceeding without Captain Sisko?
I'm sure the Emissary would like to be here, but under the circumstances...
May I have your attention.

I've been looking forward to this day for many years as I'm sure all of you have. Welcoming a new planet to the Federation is the happiest assignment an admiral can hope for. Maybe that's why so many of us showed up.
The Federation is not just a union of planets, it's much more --
Emissary...
Get him to the Infirmary.
No! I have to tell them.
What is it, Emissary? Have the Prophets revealed something to you?
The locusts... they'll destroy Bajor... unless it stands alone.
It's too soon. Bajor must not Join the Federation. If it does, it will be destroyed.
His entire central nervous system is depolarizing. We have to operate immediately.
Then what are you waiting for?
Captain Sisko made it clear that he didn't want surgery.
What are you suggesting, Major? We stand around and let him die?
No. But this isn't about what I want... or what you want. This is about Captain Sisko. And he told us he doesn't want anything to interfere with his visions.
Major, these visions may be important, but I think we're all in agreement here that they're not as important as Captain Sisko's life. Start the procedure.
It's not that simple.
Captain Sisko refused surgery. And I can't go against the decision of my patient. Not without the consent of his closest relative.
I guess that means it's up to me.
Dad... I know you want to see this to the end. But... I need you... I'm sorry.
Do what you have to do.
Prepare for surgery. I'm sorry, but you're all going to have to leave now.
Any news about the Emissary?
He's still in surgery.
I hope the Prophets will forgive us. we never should have allowed the Federation to interfere with the Emissary's visions.
It wasn't the Federation. It was his son. And he had every right to make that decision.
It was a selfish act.
He's an eighteen-year-old boy who doesn't want to lose his father. What would you have done in his place?
I would have trusted the Prophets.
Maybe we're the ones who need to trust the Prophets. For all we know, this is part of their plan.
Maybe they've already told Captain Sisko everything they want him to know.
Perhaps. I suppose you've heard... Bajor will not be joining the Federation today. The Council of Ministers have voted to delay acceptance of Federation membership.
You must be very pleased.
I wish I were. But things aren't so simple. Not anymore. Before Captain Sisko found B'hala, my path was clear. I knew who my enemies were... but now... now nothing is certain.
No...
No.
You took them away.
We had no choice. You were dying.
I almost had it. Almost understood it all.
Now it's gone.
Yes.
How are you feeling?
I'm fine, admiral.
Look Ben, it's not too late. You could contact the Chamber of Ministers. Tell them you were wrong. Convince them to accept Federation membership.

I can't do that. The visions may have faded, but everything I said, everything I did, still feels right. When I said Bajor should wait before it joins the Federation, I never felt so certain about anything in my life.
I was afraid you'd say that, Ben. I could have your commission for this.
I know.
But considering how the Bajorans feel about you, if I pulled you from this post, we'd probably lose Bajor forever.
Admiral, for what it's worth I wish things had turned out differently.
So do I.
But it's not over. One day Bajor will join the Federation. That much, I'm sure of.
Are you speaking as a Starfleet Captain or as the Emissary of the Prophets?
Both.
In that case, I'll keep the champagne on ice.
You're just in time, Dad.
What's this all about?
It's about jambalaya.
We never had that welcome back dinner for Kasidy.
Welcome back. To both of us.
Ben... I can't say I understand what you've gone through. I know you feel you've lost something important... and maybe you have. But believe me...
... you've held on to something important as well.
Captain's Log, Stardate 50814.2. The Defiant is returning to Deep Space Nine after a weeklong reconnaissance mission in the Gamma Quadrant.
I can't wait to get home and sleep in my own bed... the bunks on this ship are so uncomfortable.
You know what I could use? A weekend at the Golian Spa.
Maybe you and Shakaar can slip away when we get back?
We're not seeing each other anymore.
When did this happen?
Last week.
No wonder you've been so down lately.
I miss him. But last time we were on Bajor, we went to the Kenda Shrine and asked the Prophets if we were meant to walk the same path.
And?
We're not.
You make it sound so... cut and dry.
The way I see it, people are either meant to be together or they're not.
I guess I'd rather believe that any relationship can work if both people really want it to.
I'm not sure I have an opinion on the subject...
Excuse me. I need to regenerate.
Is he all right?
You know Odo. This sort of talk makes him uncomfortable.
I'm trying to cut down.
I'm making Molly a dollhouse for her birthday.
The house itself was easy, but the furniture -- even with a micro- lathe, I'm not sure I'm going to be able to finish it all in time.
I guess her dolls are going to have to rough it for a while.
Hmm, interesting. I'm getting some unusual readings from a nearby solar system.
What kind of readings?
There's some sort of energy barrier surrounding the fourth planet.
It's hard to tell from all the interference, but there could be lifeforms on the surface.
If there are, I'd be interested to see how they've adapted to the quantum fluctuations in the barrier.
Maybe we can check it out the next time we come this way.
It'll be too late -- at the rate the interference is intensifying, in another few weeks, we won't even be able to send a probe through it.
Dax...
I know everyone wants to go home, but if we're going to take a look at this planet, this is our only chance.
You're sure it's safe to pass through the interference?
A few modifications to the shields and it'll be smooth sailing...
All right. We'll make a quick survey.
But if all we detect is some fungus, we're not beaming down.
What if it's a smart fungus?
We're approaching the barrier...
All right, old man. Take us in.
Adjusting shield harmonics to compensate...
The quantum fluctuations are intensifying...
We're through...
Are you all right?
I think so...
Doctor Bashir to the Bridge...
I'm fine.
The inertial dampers are off-line, and the gyromagnetic stabilizers have depolarized. We're going to be here for days.
Smooth sailing?
Sir, we are being hailed from the surface.
There are several settlements scattered across the southern peninsula. I'm reading approximately eight thousand inhabitants... they appear to be human.
On screen.
Welcome to Gaia, Captain Sisko.
You know my name.
We've been expecting you.
It's a long story, Benjamin. Why don't you come down and we'll talk about it over some raktajino. I forgot. You're trying to cut down.
Miranda O'Brien.
Yedrin... Yedrin Dax.
What a coincidence...
Would one of you mind telling us what's going on here?
This settlement was founded by the crew of a Starfleet vessel that crashed on this planet two centuries ago. I realize this is going to be hard for you to accept... but that ship was the Defiant.

Two days from now, when you leave here and try to pass through the energy barrier, you'll be thrown back in time two hundred years. You'll be stranded here... and become the founders of this settlement. We're... your descendents.
Go ahead, Jadzia. Scan me -- you'll find the Dax symbiont right here.
It's true.
The symbiont has been passed down to Jadzia's descendents for three generations. I remember all of you like it was yesterday.
If you scan Miranda, you'll find that her DNA is substantially similar to the chief's.
She's an O'Brien, all right.
And a Tannenbaum, too.
As in... Ensign Tannenbaum? From Engineering?
You and Rita were married ten years after the Defiant crashed.

You were trapped here, Miles. Two hundred years in the past. There was no going home, no chance of ever seeing your family again. You were the last to give up hope... but eventually, you realized you had to make a new life for yourself here.

I know that face, Benjamin. You're still not convinced we're telling the truth. If you want, I could tell you something only Curzon would know. Remember that dancer you met on Pelios station? The one who --
That'll do, thank you.
Are you the Son of Mogh?
I am.
Is it true you can kill someone just by looking at them?
Only if I am angry.
Why don't we go inside? You can meet some of the others later. We still have a lot to talk about.
Ready for the next problem?
This is our meeting hall... Which as you can see, we sometimes use as a schoolroom.

Say you have twenty-seven tessipates of land you want to plant with nice juicy yelg melons. Yum. If each melon needs one square kerripate to grow in, what's the total number of melons you can plant? Let me know as soon as you have an answer.
Jadzia designed it as an educational program. She took Quark's image from the Defiant's security logs. I've always thought Quark would make a great math teacher, he's so good with numbers.
I like your spots.
Most people don't have them because our ancestors were mostly human. My mother says they make me special.
It's just genetics, Lisa. Like Torvin's ridges.
You're just jealous, Molly.
Molly?
There are a lot of them around here. The name's been passed down through the O'Brien line.
Molly, this is your grandfather's great-great-great grandfather.
Hello.
Hi.
How much were we... ... were you able to salvage from the Defiant?
A portable generator, a replicator... a few phasers and tricorders -- that sort of thing.
Did anyone ever try to send out a distress signal?
To who? It was two hundred years ago.
The wormhole hadn't been discovered yet... there was no way to get back to the Alpha Quadrant.
Our ancestors decided to make this their new home.
They needed to build a shelter quickly, before the winter came.
This is it -- it's the oldest building there is. At first, everyone had to sleep in here -- all forty-eight of them.
Forty-eight?
Kira died a few weeks after the crash. The energy discharge that struck her on the bridge damaged her neural pathways. The Defiant didn't have the medical equipment Julian needed to treat her.
Do you want to see where she's buried?
Maybe later.
Girls, why don't you run along and help your parents? It's almost time for planting and there's a lot to be done.
Bye.
Obviously we need to get Kira back to the station for treatment as soon as we can repair the Defiant.
Of course.
I don't quite know how to say this... but now that we know about the accident that sent the ship back in time, we should be able to avoid it.
If we do that, your timeline will collapse... and everything here will cease to exist.

Not necessarily. I have a plan. The key to it is what happened to Kira on the Bridge. The energy discharge caused a subspace doubling effect. For an instant, every molecule in her body had a corresponding quantum duplicate -- there were literally two Kiras.
Go on.
If we make certain modifications to the Defiant's systems, we should be able to amiplify the doubling effect and create a quantum duplicate of the entire ship.
When you encounter the temporal anomaly...
The duplicate will be thrown back into the past, and the original -- you -- will pass through the barrier unaffected.
We go home, and your timeline is preserved.
Exactly.
What do you think?
It might work.
According to the logs I retrieved from the wreckage, the Defiant encountered the anomaly thirty- nine hours after it arrived in orbit.
If your plan is going to work, we must do the same.
There are almost eight thousand people living on this planet. This is the only chance they have.
Dax, I want a full evaluation as soon as possible. If the plan is sound, start making the modifications immediately.
Thank you, Benjamin.
Anything for you... Old man.
Apparently the planet is crawling with Bashirs...
Maybe I'll stay up here...
How's Odo?
Resting comfortably. But he can't hold his shape because of the quantum fluctuations inside the barrier.
Sweet dreams... As soon as we leave orbit, he'll be right as rain.
You, on the other hand, are going to have to undergo a complete neural pathway induction as soon as we get back to the station.
If you say so. I feel fine.
That's because your neural tissues haven't begun to deteriorate. But rest assured... -- you'll be on my operating table eventually.
Where are you off to?
I want to get down there -- meet some Bashirs.
Hello, Nerys.
Odo... ?
I came up from the surface as soon as I heard you were here.
How are you holding your shape? (glancing at the other Odo) I thought --
I learned to counter the barrier's effects a long time ago.
It's good to see you...
You look different.
I've gotten better at shape-shifting over the years.
You're as beautiful as I remember...
You don't know how I've longed to hear your voice... see your smile.
Odo... what's gotten into you?
There's something I want you to know... something I've wanted to tell you for two hundred years....
I love you, Nerys. I've always loved you.
Wait a minute... what do you mean you love me?
Is it so hard to believe?
I never knew you felt that way about me.
I did everything I could to make sure you didn't find out.
It worked. Why didn't you ever say anything?
I didn't think you could possibly care for me the way I cared for you. I suppose I was afraid of ruining what we had. Our friendship meant everything to me. It still does.
Maybe I shouldn't have said anything.
No, it's not that. I'm just thinking about all the times I came to you for advice about Shakaar. And Bareil. It must've been so hard for you to listen to me go on about another man.
I can't say I enjoyed it. But I wanted to be a good friend to you.
You were.

Nerys, I didn't come here expecting you to throw yourself in my arms. But you're leaving here in two days, and I'm never going to see you again. All I'm asking is that you... spend some time with me. Gaia is very beautiful... I'd love to show it to you.
I'd like that.
She has your eyes...
You think?
Dax to Sisko.
Go ahead.
Good news, Benjamin.
I've gone over the sensor logs from the crash.
It looks like Yedrin's plan to create a duplicate Defiant is going to work.
Did you hear that? Hmm? Everything's going to be all right.
Sounds like you have your hands full down there, Benjamin.
You could say that...
We'll keep you posted.
Thirsty?
The captain asked me to make a survey of the settlement's infrastructure so we can leave behind appropriate supplies.
I was just doing the same thing at the clinic.
I met one of my descendents.
My great-great-great-great granddaughter... The doctor.
She made quite a fuss over me. Apparently my "healing touch" is something of a legend around here.
They're here!
Who?
The Klingons!
Q'apla.
Q'apla.
We are the Sons of Mogh.
You are my descendents?
Some by blood, some by choice. Our hearts are Klingon. We live as warriors. Just as you taught our ancestors long ago.
I'm going to be one of them someday. I'll ride a wild torga, and go hunting -- and only come to the settlement to trade furs for the things I need.
When you're older, you'll have the chance to prove yourself. If you are worthy, you can take a Klingon name and live among us.
The Sons of Mogh are gathering to celebrate your return. It would honor us greatly if you would feast with us tonight.
I look forward to it.
We'll come for you at nightfall.
Well... looks like I'm not the only legend around here...
Once the emitter array is re- calibrated, we can start synchronizing the shield generators.
Good, we're ahead of schedule.
What?
You just reminded me of something. The summer after the crash, it was so hot Jadzia cut her hair short. Worf hated it.
I remember promising to grow it back in time for the wedding.
We got married?
The next fall. Benjamin performed the ceremony. I'll never forget Worf's voice when he said the vows. It was shaking.
Were we happy together?
He's a good man, Jadzia.
I know. It's just sometimes he's so hard to get along with.
Don't worry. You'll learn to handle him.
Maybe you're thinking I should've known, should've guessed. But I didn't have any idea. You realize that, don't you?
I know you can't answer me, I'm not even sure you can hear me.
But if you can... I just want to say that I'm sorry I didn't see it sooner. I'm sorry if I hurt you in any way. I didn't mean to.
You're probably wondering what's going to happen next. So am I. The only thing I know for sure is that I don't want anything to get in the way of our friendship.
But do me a favor... if there's anything else you're keeping from me, any other deep dark secret I should know about but don't -- just tell me, okay?
Hi.
Excuse me...
Did I mention she was a doctor?
Twice.
She showed me pictures of the family going all the way back to me. Know who I ended up with after the crash?
Angie Kirby.
Who's that?
That's what I said. Apparently she transferred aboard last week. She's gorgeous.
Congratulations.
When we get back, I'm thinking of asking her out. We obviously got along here.
So... you and Rita Tannenbaum.
I don't want to hear it, Julian. I have a wife and kids back home.
Sorry... I didn't mean anything...
I'll let you get on with your work...
Praying over your own grave... that's got to be a new one.
If the Prophets were listening, they're probably very confused.
I wouldn't blame them. I've got to tell you... this whole quantum duplicate, two Defiants thing has me feeling a little strange.
Why? Thanks to Yedrin's plan our timeline is being preserved, and you're going back to the station for the treatment you need.
I know. It's just... I've always believed we're only given one Destiny. One path. And now we're going to use technology to get around that; I'm not sure how it makes me feel.
I know exactly how it makes me feel.

You don't know how much it means to me to know you're going home, Nerys. It won't change things for me -- I lost you two hundred years ago. But for the other Odo up on the ship, it changes everything. He doesn't have to lose you. And somehow, knowing that makes me feel better. Does that make any sense?
You've changed so much, Odo. I don't just mean the way you look. You used to be so... closed off.
I have changed. And the Odo you know will change too... (gently testing the water) -- if you're patient with him.
Why don't we head back?
Nice catch --

We need to talk. I was looking over the sensor logs from the crash and I came across something odd -- the quantum fluctuations in the barrier factored out to zero. The chances of that must be a billion to one.
What are you getting at?
Yedrin faked the logs.
Why would he do that?
So we'd think his plan was going to work. It's not.
There was never going to be a duplicate Defiant -- just one. And Yedrin wanted to make sure it would go back in time.
So that history would repeat itself...
If I hadn't realized what he'd done, we would've ended up stranded here... and Kira would've died.
You betrayed us. You betrayed me. You call yourself Yedrin Dax, but you're not anyone I recognize.
Now that you know... what are you going to do about it?
What do you think?
Dammit, Ben -- if you don't take the Defiant back in time, the eight thousand people on this planet will cease to exist!
Do you think I don't care? Come on, you know me better than that. But what am I supposed to do -- recreate the accident and deliberately maroon my crew?
It's what would've happened! Who's to say it's not what's supposed to happen?
I'm not going to stand here and argue philosophy with you. I have a duty to protect my people.

Look around you, Ben. Think of all the things you've seen since you got here. This is what your crew and their descendents will build if you let history play itself out. I'm not saying it won't be hard at first, but they'll have good lives here. Happy lives.
What about Kira? If we don't get her back to the station, she'll die.
Is one life too much to ask if it means saving eight thousand?
Who are you to decide who lives and who dies? Who are you to make that call?
I have to make that call! Because I'm responsible for what happened here!

Jadzia knows what I'm talking about. She's the one who insisted the Defiant investigate this planet. You know as well as I do that you should've been more careful... you should've seen that the barrier was unstable when you scanned it.
But I didn't. I was so bent on making some great discovery that I missed it.

And because of you, because of me -- Kira died, and forty-eight people were stranded here. You don't know what it was like to live with that. For years, every time I looked at you, all I could think of was Jake... and how because of me, he'd never see his father again. But eventually, I had to accept the fact that there was nothing I could do to change things. I couldn't bring Kira back. All I could do was look to the future. And make sure we survived. No matter what. This community is my responsibility. For two centuries, I've watched it grow into something to be proud of. These people have worked for generations to make a life for themselves here, and they deserve the chance to hang on to it.

I'm not denying that. I wish there was a way we could help you... but my people have the right to go home to their families. And I can't ask Kira to sacrifice her life, not for eight thousand people, not for eight million. No one has the right to ask that...
I'm sorry, old man... there's nothing I can do...
Look at them. They have no idea what's going to happen.
It's for the best. They are children. They would not understand.
I'm not sure I understand, either...
Eight thousand people, Worf... and they're all going to die because I have to go back to the station to be treated for some condition I can't even tell I have.
That is not the only reason we are going back, major. Do not blame yourself.
I'm going up to the ship.
